Posts.Content: Hi Snowys Mum I have my tattoos and start treatment 28/12 and it is as you say 14 over 3 weeks. It's good to hear of your relatively good experience with radiotherapy. It makes me feel a bit better about it all. Kate, the Macmillan Radiotherapy Expert, reassured me that having radiotherapy was the right thing to do after a lumpectomy.  I think it will help to lesson the worry about recurrence which we may have. As I had left breast cancer I have to do this 20sec deep breath holding to keep the heart out of the way. Practising with my head in a bowl of water daily. It's certainly helping and I'm getting better at it. Wishing you all a lovely Christmas and New Year. Syl
Posts.Title: DCIS and radio

Posts.Content: Hello again London Lass I seem to have pressed the wrong button. I was just saying that the time between appointments is very long but they do understand pain and try all sorts of things. I was prescribed some sticky patches that I put on the area of pain. They remained on for 12hrs every night. They also take time to work. They may help you but didn't do much for me.  Keep going.  We are all rooting for you. Syl
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Your right Nicky. None of us should feel so bad about ourselves. It's tough trying to keep a sunny face especially when you are so tired. London Lass you are going to feel quite a lot better with the new pills if it is amitryptaline which in small doses it works very well for neuropathic pain. It can work quite quickly.  Changing the subject back to R1and R2 creams for radiotherapy. I have asked the pharmacist at the GP's surgery but she can't find it on the system. I have written down the code for prescribing but forgot to write down who it was manufactured by so as to go to my local pharmacy. Thanks .Syl
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hello Toxophilite I will try the Zero tabs. Do you get them from the chemist?
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?
How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Thanks Toxophilite, will check out Amazon. Hadn't thought of them. Syl
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hi London Lass I too struggled with pain for months and tried all the pain meds which didn't seem to help at all. The pain was severe as soon as I lay down. The GP was very understanding and listened finally putting me on Pregabalin, which is the same as Gabapentin I think. It doesn't work straight away but makes you feel sleepy. In fact it took weeks to have the desired effect and is working well now. At the Pain Clinic they have just tested the nerves on that side. I am waiting for the results of that but don't have an appointment until the beginning of January. Unreal. I suppose they are very busy. There is always a long time between appointments at the
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Well done. May the wind be in your sails and blow away any cobwebs. Syl
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Well done. May the wind be in your sails and blow away any cobwebs. Syl
Posts.Title: Rang that bell yesterday!

Posts.Content: Hi Lynn i found the site very clear and interesting. I think our hospitals practise all these suggestions from Australia .Syl
Posts.Title: Best practice in breast cancer care

Posts.Content: Hello Lynn ja, the finger nails only started flaking in the last couple of months but the horrible toenails have been with me for months. Will try the nail hardening treatment and more magnesium. Thanks. Syl
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: I have just finish treatment for breast cancer HR2 pos and had 4 intravenous chemo with the herceptin and continued on to complete a course of 18 herceptin. The last shot was two weeks ago and I have been very sleepy since then most of the time. I put it down to being old 77yrs and coping with long term  type one diabetes. On top of which I have a pesky head cold. Ja, the drippy nose has been with me for a long time but didn't connect it with the herceptin. So that will will be nice when it goes. My toe nails started to become a problem some time ago and look ghastly. The podiatrist trimmed them as best she could and reassured me that they would come through good again. The finger nails have also been affected and they are flaky and break easily thus I am almost down to the quicks. A small price to pay when you think about what other people go through. Glad that the cancer was diagnosed and dealt with quickly and and efficiently. I consider myself very fortunate.
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: Ja, I tried something similar but no help to me unfortunately. Would be nice to have such an innocuous treatment instead of quinine tabs and I am willing to try most suggestions. Having banana, spinach, Tumeric and ginger in a kefir smoothie every day to try all. Some nights it's ok so that's good. Syl
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects

Posts.Content: Thanks G 'n J I do have quinine tabs from the dr but she doesn't like me to take them on a regular basis so I just take the odd one here and there. Usually it's in the middle of the night after a particularly nasty episode of cramp in both thighs or both calves and I have to walk around for quite a while until the cramp goes. I am trying magnesium tabs and orange juice daily as suggested. I can go for several days without any cramp at all but I think I have always had a bit of a problem before the cancer only now it is much much worse and lasts for longer. That's why I thought it may have something to do with the herceptin. Syl
Posts.Title: Herceptin effects
